introduction.title: (Calculus) Formula for Intenssity
introduction.p: It turns out that figuring out intensity in the diffraction pattern is not so easy as finding the directions of the minima. We must apply the superposition principle to the waves, and then, find the time-average of the square of the sum.

We will use to perform out calculations. I have placed a z axis at the slit to refer to parts of the wavefront there. Let y axis be pointed into the page and x axis pointed to the right. Note that this figure shows only a cross-section of the wavefront at the slit since the wavefront is parallel to the yz plane.

figure.caption: Geometry for the calculation of Fraunhofer diffraction from plane wave at a slit. We assume electric field to be mostly along z axis. Here \hat u_z is unit vector towards positive z axis. dz shows a small part of the wavefront at coordinate z.

introduction.p:
We will also assume that electric field is mostly the z component. Therefore, work with just the E_z wave and call E_z by E. Let A denote the voltage per unit length at the wavefront. Then, we can write the electric field wave at point P on the screen which started at dz of the wavefront as a spherical wave as follows.
dE = \frac{A dz}{r}\cos(kr - \omega t),
Adz/r is the amplitude of this wave when it arrives at P, k is the wavenumber, which is related to wavelength \lambda by
k = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda},
\omega is the angular frequency, which is related to the frequency f by
\omega = 2\pi f.

From triangle, whose vertices are O, P, and dz, we get the following for r^2.
r^2 \amp = \left( \frac{R}{\cos\theta} \right)^2 + z^2 - 2 \frac{zR}{\cos\theta}\cos\left( \frac{\pi}{2} - \theta\right) \amp = \left( \frac{R}{\cos\theta} \right)^2 + z^2 - 2 \frac{zR}{\cos\theta}\sin \theta.

Now, since z will be a point on the wavefront at the slit, its range of value is limited,
-\frac{b}{2} \le z \le \frac{b}{2}.
Since \frac{R}{\cos\theta} \gt \gt b, we can drop z^2 in r^2 to get
r^2 \approx \left( \frac{R}{\cos\theta} \right)^2 - 2 \frac{zR}{\cos\theta}\sin \theta.
Taking square root of both sides we get
r = \frac{R}{\cos\theta} \left( 1 - 2 \frac{z \cos\theta}{R}\sin \theta \right)^{1/2}.
Here since |z|\lt \lt R, we can expand the quantity in parenthesis and keep upto two terms so that we have dependence on z still there.
r = \frac{R}{\cos\theta} - z \sin\theta.
We make one more simplification here. Since \theta will be small, we can replace \cos\theta by 1. To be consistent, we could replace \sin\theta by \theta in radians, but, it is customary to leave \sin\theta alone here. Finally, we have the following simplified expression for r.
r = R - z \sin\theta.

In Eq. , distance r appears in the amplitude \frac{Adz}{r} and in phase kr - \omega t. Since |z\sin \theta| \lt\lt R we may be tempted to drop z\sin \theta altogether. Since kr in the phase has a large k, small changes in kr have large impact on sine of kr . Therefore, in the phase we must keep z\sin \theta. Dropping z\sin \theta in the the amplitude \frac{Adz}{r} does not have much impact. Thus, Eq. simplifies to
dE \approx \frac{(Adz)}{R}\sin\left[ k(R-z\sin\theta) - \omega t\right]
Now, we just integrate this over the wavefront, from z=-b/2 to z=+b/2, to get the electric field at P which is in the direction \theta from the slit.
E_P = \frac{A}{R} \left[ \frac{2\sin\left(\frac{kb}{2}\sin\theta\right)}{kb\sin\theta} \right]\ \sin\left[ kR - \omega t\right].

Intensity at in the direction \theta is proportional to time average of this fluctuating field. Since time averaging of \sin^2(\omega t) and \cos^2(\omega t) give \frac{1}{2}, after calculations, we end up with the following for intensity.
I(\theta)=\epsilon_0 c \left( \frac{bA}{R} \right)^2 \left[ \frac{\sin\beta}{\beta} \right]^2,
where symbol \beta stands for
\beta = \frac{\pi b \sin\theta}{\lambda}.
Let us denote the intensity in the \theta_0 direction by I_0. Since sin x/x = 1 when x=0, from Eq. we get
I_0 = \epsilon_0 c \left( \frac{bA}{R} \right)^2.
This helps us write intensity in direction \theta in terms of I_0. We rewrite Eq. as
I(\theta) = I_0 \left( \frac{\sin\beta(\theta)}{\beta(\theta)} \right)^2.

subsection.title: Diffraction Maxima and Minima
subsection.p: We now use the formula for intensity to find the values of \beta in which intensity will have maxima and minima. After we get these \beta values, we use Eq. to obtain angles \theta which give us the directions from the center of the slit.

First we notice that when \beta = 0, sin\beta /\beta is not zero, but it is equal to 1. For \beta = m^\prime \pi for non-zero integer m, \sin\beta /\beta is zero. Therefore, we have all the betas for which we will have zero intensity, which are the minima here. Let us give subscripts to these betas.
\text{Minima: }\ \beta_{m^\prime} = m^\prime \pi\ \ (m^\prime \text{ nonzero integer})
Using Eq. , these will corresponds to the following in terms of angles. Giving subscripts to these thetas we have.
\frac{\pi b \sin\theta_{m^\prime}}{\lambda} = m^\prime \pi.
Rearranging this gives us the result we obtained by a trick in .
\text{Minima: }\ b\sin\theta = m^\prime \lambda \ \ (m^\prime \text{ nonzero integer})

The intensity maxima do not occur at points halfway between the minima. Instead we must find \beta values at the maxima of intensity I by treating I(\beta) as a function of \beta. By setting the derivative dI/d\beta to zero, we will get both maxima and minima, and since we already know the minima, we will identify the maxima by removing the minima from the list. dB/d\beta=0 gives
\frac{1}{\beta^3}\sin(\beta) \left(\beta\cos\beta -\sin\beta \right) = 0.
Of the three factors, we can drop \/\beta^3=0, and ge the following conditions for maxima and minima.
\amp \sin\beta = 0. \amp \beta\cos\beta -\sin\beta = 0.
The first condition includes one maximum at \beta = 0, and the rest of the betas are minima as discussed above.

The second equation corresponds to only maxima. You can verify that this is the case by using second derivative test. Now, you shoudl notice that, unlike solving \sin\beta = 0, solving \beta\cos\beta -\sin\beta = 0 is no easy task. This equation is a transcendental equation and can be solved graphically.

Before, we solve Eq. , by dividing by \cos\theta we convert this equation to the following since it is easier to see when \tan\beta and \beta cross than when beta\cos\beta -\sin\beta = 0 and \sin\beta cross.
\tan\beta = \beta.
We now plot \tan \beta and \beta versus \beta as shown in . The approximate solutions for the maxima can be read off from the graphs, for instance, 0, \pm\frac{3}{2}\pi, \pm\frac{5}{2}\pi, etc.
We can plot I/I_0 versus \beta or versus \theta. When you plot I/I_0 versus \beta, the minima will occur at non-zero integer multiples of \pi, which correspond to \theta between -\pi/2 and \pi/2.

shows three plots of I/I_0 correponding to three cases of slit width compared to wavelength: b=\lambda/2, b=\lambda, and b=2\lambda. The b=\lambda/2 is too narrow a slit to have diffraction minima and shows what to expect if you have very narrow opening. The b=2\lambda shows five diffraction maxima, and b=\lambda is the borderline case which just shows noticeably pointed spread in intensity and no minima.

figure.caption: A plot of diffraction pattern for various slit widths. Only with slit width greater than the wavelength that we would observe diffraction maxima and minima.

subsection.p: If you plotted I/I_0 versus \beta, the central peak will go from \beta=-\pi to \beta=\pi at the base. That is the central peak covers a range of \Delta\beta=2\pi. The other peaks cover half as wide a range. For instance, the first side peak goes from \beta=\pi to \beta=2\pi, which gives it a range of \Delta\beta=\pi only.

exercise.title: Widths and Positions of Diffraction Through a Single Wide Slit

statement.p: Monochromatic light of wavelength 530 nm passes through a horizontal single slit of width 1.5 \mum in an opaque plate. A screen of dimensions 2 m \times 2 m is 1.2 m away from the slit. (a) Which way is the diffraction pattern spread out on the screen? (b) What are the directions of the minima? (c) What are the directions of the maxima? (d) How wide is the central bright fringe on the screen? (e) How wide is the next bright fringe on the screen?

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) Since the slit is horizontal, the diffraction pattern will be vertical.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The diffraction minima from a single slit occur when \beta = m \pi for m = \pm1,\: \pm 2,\: \cdots. In terms of the slit width b and the direction \theta vertically from the slit this condition becomes
\dfrac{\pi b \sin\:\theta_m}{\lambda} = m \pi,\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ b\:\sin\:\theta_m = m\:\lambda,\ \ m = \pm1,\: \pm 2,\: \cdots.
Using this formula we obtain the following values for \theta_1, \theta_2 and \theta_3.
\amp \theta_1 = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{\lambda}{b} \right) = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{530\:\text{nm}}{1500\:\text{nm}} \right) = 0.36\:\text{rad} = 21^{\circ}, \amp \theta_2 = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2\lambda}{b} \right) = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2\times530\:\text{nm}}{1500\:\text{nm}} \right) = 0.78\:\text{rad} = 45^{\circ}, \amp \theta_3 = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{3\lambda}{b} \right) = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{3\times530\:\text{nm}}{1500\:\text{nm}} \right) = \sin^{-1}\left(>1\right).
That means \theta_3 does not exist. Therefore, the positions of the first and second order spots on the screen will be given by the y-coordinates,
\amp y_{\pm 1} =L\:\tan(\theta_{\pm1}) =(1.2\:\text{m})\:\tan(\pm 21^{\circ}) = \pm 46\:\text{cm}, \amp y_{\pm 2} =L\:\tan(\theta_{\pm2}) =(1.2\:\text{m})\:\tan(\pm 45^{\circ}) = \pm 1.2\:\text{cm}.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Maxima when \beta = 0, \pm 1.4303\:\pi, \pm 2.4590\:\pi, \cdots. Therefore, the bright spots will be in the following directions.
\amp \theta_0 = 0^{\circ},\ \ \text{central bright spot}, \amp \theta_1 = \sin^{-1}\left( \dfrac{1.4303\:\lambda}{b}\right) = 30^{\circ}, \amp \theta_2 = \sin^{-1}\left( \dfrac{2.4590\:\lambda}{b}\right) = 60^{\circ}.
The y-coordinates of these bright spots are
y_0 = 0,\ \ y_{\pm 1} = 69.3\:\text{cm},\ \ y_{\pm 2} = 2.1\:\text{m}.
Since the screen is only 2 m x 2 m, the second order spot will not be on the screen. \item The width of the central bright spot will be between the y_{-1} and y_{+1} of the diffraction minima worked out in part (a).
\Delta y_{\text{central}} = y_{+1} - y_{-1} = 46\:\text{cm} - (-46\:\text{cm}) = 92\:\text{cm}.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
The m=1 bright spot will be between y_{+1} and y_{+2} of the diffraction minima. Therefore, the width of the m=1 bright spot will be
\Delta y_{\text{m=1}} = \left[y_{+2} - y_{+1}\right]_{\text{min}} = 1.2\:\text{m} - (46\:\text{cm}) = 74\:\text{cm}.

exercise.title: Width of a Single Slit from Width of Central Maximum on Screen

statement.p: A monochromatic light of wavelength 632.8 nm incident on a single slit has central bright spot of width 5 cm at a screen 1.6 m away. Find the width of the slit.

hint.p: you can get width of the central maximum from diffraction minima around the central maximum.

solution.p:
From the given data we can find the direction to the m=1 minimum.
\theta_1 = \tan^{-1} \left( \dfrac{2.5\:\text{cm}}{160\:\text{cm}} \right) = 0.895^{\circ}.
Therefore,
b\:\sin\:\theta_1 = 1\:\lambda,\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ b = \dfrac{\lambda}{\sin\:\theta_1}.
Hence,
b = \dfrac{632.8\:\text{nm}}{\sin\:0.895^{\circ}} = 40.5\:\mu\text{m}.

exercise.title: Separation of Two Wavelengths in a Single-slit Diffraction

statement.p: A source of light having two wavelength 550 nm and 600 nm of equal intensity is incident on a slit of width 1.8 \mum. Find the separation of the m = 1 bright spots of the two wavelengths on a screen 30 cm away.

hint.p: First find the directions of m=1 maxima for each wavelength.

solution.p:
From the condition for the diffraction maxima we have b\:\sin\:\theta = 1.4303\:\lambda for m=1 maximum. Therefore, we would get following angles for the two wavelengths.
\amp \theta_{550} = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1.4303\times 550\:\text{nm}}{1800\:\text{nm}} \right) = 26^{\circ}, \amp \theta_{600} = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1.4303\times 600\:\text{nm}}{1800\:\text{nm}} \right) = 29^{\circ}.
Since the distance to the screen in 30 cm the y-coordinates of the spots will be
\amp y_{550} = 30\:\text{cm}\:\tan\:26^{\circ} = 14.6\:\text{cm}, \amp y_{600} = 30\:\text{cm}\:\tan\:29^{\circ} = 16.7\:\text{cm}.
Therefore the peaks of the spots are separated by \Delta y = 2.1 cm.

exercise.title: Intensity of Light in a Particular Direction behind a Single Slit

statement.p: A single slit of width 3.0 \mum is illuminated by a sodium yellow light of wavelength 589 nm. Find the intensity at a 15^{\circ} angle to the axis in terms of the intensity of the central maximum which can be taken to be 1 unit.

solution.p:
The intensity in the diffraction pattern of a single slit is given by
I(\theta) = I(0)\:\left( \dfrac{\sin\:\beta(\theta)}{\beta(\theta)}\right)^2,
where \beta(\theta) = \pi\:b\:\sin\:\theta/\lambda. Let us find \beta for the given angle.
\beta(15^{\circ}) = \dfrac{\pi \times 3.0\: \mu\text{m}\:\sin\:15^{\circ}}{0.589\:\mu\text{m}}=4.14\:\text{rad}.
Therefore, our answer will be
\dfrac{I(\theta)}{I(0)} = \left( \dfrac{\sin\: (4.14\:\text{rad} )}{4.14\:\text{rad}}\right)^2 = 0.04.
